I love this code because it shows so clearly the problems with the current syntax of Python.
You can imagine a code review for a new developer:
1\. "Why is the name of your class'my_class' and not 'MyClass'?"
2\. "Why did you use an empty string as the strongest extension? Didn't you read the code?"
3\. "What if someone changes the name of the class or the name of the strongest extension? This code is all wrong."

A simple fix would be to allow a block to be passed as the last argument, which would contain a call to __repr__.

1\. Readability of the function will improve.
2\. You will not have to deal with the empty string issue anymore.
3\. The function will become reusable for classes with more than one string extension.
4\. Code that is easy to understand is more likely to be correct.

There is a bug in this code. When comparing for equality, Python compares the
length of the strings rather than the contents. This means that
'aaa' == 'aaa'
is true, whereas
'aaaa'!= 'aaa'
is false.
There is a simple workaround, but it is a pain: if you need to compare for
equality, you have to use str.equals.

This is why the 3rd example above, "my_class.AA", works and the first
example, "my_class =='my_class.AA'", does not.

This is a variation on the "Minimum length subsequence" problem. I ran it through some instances to test its performance, and it came out a little slow (around 7 seconds, but I'm not sure what was going on since it should be O(N). I did notice that you are calling memcmp for every possible substring, so I would recommend using the string comparison routines from the standard library, at least in python 2.5.

For a slightly more efficient way to do this, you could use a string hashing function like sha1 and just hash every possible combination of the extensions. If you have a big dictionary of strings with their hash values, then you can use them to quickly find the extension with the highest hash value.

I think it would be clearer if you used a range to represent the strength. For example, for a,b,c to represent the strengths 'a', 'b', and 'c', you could do
return 'a' if a > b, a == b, or a < b
return 'b' if a > c, a == c, or a < c
return 'c' if a > b and a < c, a == b and a < c, or a < c
You could do the same thing with ranges for CAP and SM as well.

return 'c' if a > b and a < c

I don't think it's security-by-obscurity so much as it is a useful debugging tool.
I can see a lot of use for this in the case of dynamically loading custom DLLs for an application. I've done a similar thing in the past where I would keep track of the DLLs that an app loaded and call a method to obtain the path to the DLL it loaded. This was useful if the DLL loaded failed to load and the application crashed, it would give me some insight into the problem.

I feel like this code is too clever. There is an interesting problem with defining the strength of an extension as the number of uppercase letters minus the number of lowercase letters. This is based on the assumption that the extension can only be upper or lower case, and there are no other possibilities, i.e. no such thing as a mixed case extension.

As an aside, it is not always the case that the uppercase and lowercase versions of the same extension are identical in length. To take the example above, consider that the extensions ['AA', 'Be', 'CC'] and ['my_class','my_class'] are both shorter than ['my_class.AA','my_class.Be','my_class.CC']. The fact that'my_class' is a mixed case string allows us to get away with three lowercase letters while'my_class.AA' has to be written in all u

This is indeed a good solution for the problem at hand, but it's worth mentioning that it's not very generic.
This solution is specific to Python 2.3 (and, presumably, Python 3.3 and later, but I haven't tested). In older versions of Python, there is no method named "strongest_extension" on class objects.

The behavior of this function was "fixed" in Python 2.3 to make it more intuitive to users, but it's still worth being aware of.
I believe the OP's "inherit" method is more general than the "strongest_extension" method, in that it works on any Python version.

This is an awful interview question for many reasons.
The first is that the question itself is way too easy.
The second is that the candidate has very little information to go on. You are essentially asking the candidate to read your mind.
The third is that the answer is very subjective and difficult to argue.
I agree with the comments posted below: it's not worth asking this question.

I don't think it's a bad question, but it's not worth asking because it's not a good predictor. I'd ask questions that focus on the candidate's ability to solve problems (which is also a good predictor) rather than their ability to figure out what you want.

I'm always a bit embarrassed by these answers, as I get asked questions like this in interviews and I never have a good answer. My first response is to ask, "How do you mean, strength?"

I'm not trying to be snarky, but if you don't know what the interviewer means by "strength" then you probably aren't ready to work on a team. At least, not on a team with me.

Wow, it's been a long time since I've seen someone have to remember the order of uppercase and lowercase letters in a string.

Really? I've always used the capital and lowercase method and I've seen it used in many other places.

I prefer the mnemonic "Every uppercase letter is one more than the last, and every lowercase letter is one less than the previous"

But not all lowercase letters are less than the previous.

Do you mean, not all upper-case letters are one more than the previous, either?

No, I mean the lowercase letters aren't less than the previous.
